speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, in support of these goals, the Federal Open Market Committee kept its policy interest rate near zero and stated its expectation that an increase in this rate would soon be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee also agreed to continue reducing its net asset purchases on the schedule we announced in December—bringing them to an end in early March.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I will explain, against a backdrop of elevated inflation and a strong labor market, our policy has been adapting to the evolving economic environment, and it will continue to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Economic activity expanded at a robust pace last year, reflecting progress on vaccinations and the reopening of the economy, fiscal and monetary policy support, and the healthy financial positions of households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Indeed, the economy has shown great strength and resilience in the face of the ongoing pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recent sharp rise in COVID cases associated with the Omicron variant will surely weigh on economic growth this quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: High-frequency indicators point to reduced spending in COVID-sensitive sectors, such as travel and restaurants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And activity more broadly may also be affected as many workers are unable to report for work because of illness, quarantines, or caregiving needs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Fortunately, health experts are finding that the Omicron variant has not been as virulent as previous strains of the virus, and they expect that cases will drop off rapidly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If the wave passes quickly, the economic effects should as well, and we would see a return to strong growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That said, the implications for the economy remain uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have not lost sight of the fact that for many afflicted individuals and families, and for the health-care workers on the front lines, the virus continues to cause great hardship.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market has made remarkable progress and, by many measures, is very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Job gains have been solid in recent months, averaging 365,000 per month over the past three months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the past year, payroll employment has risen by 6.4 million jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate has declined sharply, falling 2 percentage points over the past six months to reach 3.9 percent in December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The improvements in labor market conditions have been widespread, including for workers at the lower end of the wage distribution, as well as for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Labor demand remains historically strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With constraints on labor supply, employers are having difficulties filling job openings, and wages are rising at their fastest pace in many years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While labor force participation has edged up, it remains subdued, in part reflecting the aging of the population and retirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, some who would otherwise would be seeking work report that they are out of the labor force because of factors related to the pandemic, including caregiving needs and ongoing concerns about the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The current wave of the virus may well prolong these effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over time, there are good reasons to expect some further improvements in participation and employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Supply and demand imbalances related to the pandemic and [to] the reopening of the economy have continued to contribute to elevated levels of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, bottlenecks and supply constraints are limiting how quickly production can respond to higher demand in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These problems have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated, exacerbated by waves of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While the drivers of higher inflation have been predominantly connected to the dislocations caused by the pandemic, price increases have now spread to a broader range of goods and services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages have also risen briskly, and we are attentive to the risks that persistent real wage growth in excess of productivity [growth] could put upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Like most forecasters, we continue to expect inflation to decline over the course of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand that high inflation imposes significant hardship, especially on those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we believe that the best thing we can do to support continued labor market gains is to promote a long expansion, and that will require price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to our price-stability goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will use our tools both to support the economy and a strong labor market and to prevent higher inflation from becoming entrenched.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be watching carefully to see whether the economy is evolving in line with expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions have been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I noted, the Committee left the target range for the federal funds rate unchanged and reaffirmed our plan, announced in December, to end asset purchases in early March.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of the remarkable progress we’ve seen in the labor market and inflation that is well above our 2 percent longer-run goal, the economy no longer needs sustained high levels of monetary policy support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is why we are phasing out our asset purchases and why we expect it will soon be appropriate to raise the target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the economic outlook remains highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Making appropriate monetary policy in this environment requires humility, recognizing that the economy evolves in unexpected ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll need to be nimble so that we can respond to the full range of plausible outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With this in mind, we will remain attentive to risks, including the risk that high inflation is more persistent than expected, and are prepared to respond as appropriate to achieve our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To provide greater clarity about our approach for reducing the size of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet, today the Committee issued a set of principles that will provide a foundation for our future decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: [In] these high-level principles, [we] clarify that the federal funds rate is our primary means of adjusting monetary policy and that reducing our balance sheet will occur after the process of raising interest rates has begun.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reductions will occur over time in a predictable manner primarily through adjustments to reinvestments so that securities roll off our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over time, we intend to hold securities in the amounts needed for our ample-reserves operating framework, and in the longer run, we envision holding primarily Treasury securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our decisions to reduce our balance sheet will be guided by our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In that regard, we will be prepared to adjust any of the details of our approach to balance sheet management in light of economic and financial developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee has not made decisions regarding the specific timing, pace, or other details of shrinking the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will discuss these matters in upcoming meetings and provide additional information at the appropriate time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Federal Reserve will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I—as I referred to in my opening statement, it’s—it is not possible to predict with much confidence exactly what path for our policy rate is going to prove appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, at this time, we haven’t made any decisions about the path of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I stress again that we’ll be humble and nimble.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to have to navigate crosscurrents and actually two-sided risks now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and, and I’ll say also that we’re going to be guided by the data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, what I’ll say is that we’re going to be led by the incoming data and the evolving outlook, which we’ll try to communicate as clearly as possible, moving steadily and transparency—transparently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So more to your question, we know that the economy is in a very different place than it was when we began raising rates in 2015.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Specifically, the economy is now much stronger.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market is far stronger.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation is running well above our 2 percent target, much higher than it was at that time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And these differences are likely to have important implications for the appropriate pace of policy adjustments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Beyond that, we haven’t made any decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just getting both, both parts of your question written down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say—and this view is widely held on the Committee—that both sides of the mandate are calling for us to move steadily away from the very highly accommodative policies we put in place during the challenging economic conditions that the economy faced earlier in the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say that most FOMC participants agree that labor market conditions are consistent with maximum employment in the sense of the highest level of employment that is consistent with price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is—that is my personal view.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, again, very broad support on the Committee for the judgment that it will soon be appropriate to raise the target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other thing is, maximum employment will, will evolve over time and through the course of the business cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the particular situation we’re in now, it may well increase.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Max—the level of maximum—of employment that’s consistent with stable prices may increase.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we hope that it will, as more people come back into the labor market, as participation gradually rises.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the policy path that we’re broadly contemplating would be supportive of that comment—that outcome as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the thing about the labor market right now is that there are—there are many millions of, of more job openings than there are unemployed people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you ask whether we can—whether we can raise rates and, and move to less accommodative, and even tight, financial conditions without hurting the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there’s quite a bit of room to raise interest rates without threatening the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is, by so many measures, a historically tight labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Record levels of job openings, of quits.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages are moving up at the highest pace they have in decades.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at surveys of workers, they find jobs plentiful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Look at surveys of companies—they find workers scarce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And all of those readings are at levels, really, that we haven’t seen in a long time—and, in some cases, ever.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is a very, very strong labor market, and my strong sense is that we can—we can—we can move rates up without, without having to, you know, severely undermine it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also would point out that there are—there are other forces at work this year, which should also help bring down inflation, we hope, including improvement on the supply side, which will ultimately come.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The timing and pace of that are uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And also, fiscal policy is going to be less supportive of, of growth this year—not of the level of economic activity, but the fiscal impulse to growth will be significantly lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there are multiple forces—which should be working over the course of the year for inflation to come down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do realize that the timing and pace of that are, are highly uncertain and that inflation has persisted longer than we—than we thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, we’re prepared to use our tools to assure that higher inflation does not become entrenched.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m afraid to tell you that those are all great questions, and they’re questions that the Committee is just turning to now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we had—we had a discussion, as you know, at the last meeting, an introductory discussion of the balance sheet and a teeing up of the issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At this meeting, we’ve gone through and carefully put together a set of principles at a high level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are meant to guide the actual decisions we’ll make about the pace and about all of the questions that you’re, you’re asking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I expect that this process will, will be something that we spend time on in coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t tell you how many.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t tell you how long it will take.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But—and then, you know, at the appropriate time, we’ll provide additional information.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I did—the last cycle when we—when we went through balance sheet issues, we did find that over, over the course of two or three meetings, for example, we did come to interesting and better answers, we thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re just in that process now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And at the next meeting, we’ll be turning to, you know, more of the details that you’re—that you’re asking about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The balance sheet is, is much bigger.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d say it has a shorter duration than the last time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the economy’s much stronger, and inflation is much higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and I think that leads you to—and I said, I’ve said this—being willing to move sooner than we did the last time and also perhaps faster.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But beyond that, it’s really—it’s really not appropriate for me to speculate exactly what that would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and—but I would point you to principle number one, which is “the Committee views changes in the target range for the federal funds rate as its primary means of adjusting the stance of monetary policy.” So we do want the federal funds rate—we, we want to operationalize that [as the primary means].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we want the balance sheet to be declining in a predictable manner, and we want it to be declining primarily by adjusting reinvestments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, we think of the balance sheet as, as moving in a predictable manner, sort of in the background, and that the active tool meeting to meeting is not both of them, it’s the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are—there are rules of thumb—I’m reluctant to land on one of them—that, that equate this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And—but there’s also an element of, of uncertainty around the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we have a much better sense, frankly, of how rate increases affect financial conditions and, hence, economic conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Balance sheet [policy] is, is still a relatively new thing for, for the markets and for us, so we’re less certain about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, our—I think our—the pattern we’ll follow is to—is to arrive at a, you know, a timing and a pace and composition and all those things and then announce that with advance notice, and, and it will—it will start in the background.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then we’ll look to have that just running in the background and have—and have the interest rates, again, be the active tool of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s at least the plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t tell you much more about any of the—any of the very good issues about size, pace, composition, those sorts of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’ll be turning to all of those at coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you know, the ultimate focus that we have is on the real economy: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And financial conditions matter to the extent that they have implications for achieving the dual mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you also know that we, we look at broader financial conditions, not one or two things, one or two markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re looking at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t want to comment on today’s financial conditions broadly, but we’re not looking at any one market or, or so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re thinking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of what we’ve seen, I would say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, you know, we said at our last meeting we published the Summary of Economic Projections, the median of which—the median participant expected three rate increases this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s six weeks, seven weeks later now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you have seen that our communication channel with the markets is working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Markets are, are now pricing in a number of rate increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Surveys show that market participants are expecting a balance sheet runoff to begin, you know, at the appropriate time, sometime later this year perhaps.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made that decision yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we feel like the communications we have with market participants and with the general public are working and that financial conditions are reflecting in advance the decisions that we make.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And monetary policy works significantly through expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that, that in and of itself is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t got—we haven’t gotten to that point yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made a decision yet, and we’ll make that decision at the March meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll make a decision whether to raise the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say that the Committee is, is of a mind to, to raise the federal funds rate at the March meeting, assuming that conditions are appropriate for doing so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have—we have our eyes on, on the risks, particularly around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we do expect some softening in the economy from Omicron, but we think that that should be temporary.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that the economy should—the underlying strength of the economy should, you know, should, should—show through fairly quickly after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the path is highly uncertain and that we’re committed to using our tools to make sure that inflation, high inflation that we’re seeing, does not become entrenched.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So a number of factors would be—it’s not just monetary policy—a number of factors are supporting a decline in inflation, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Fiscal policy will be—will provide significantly less of an impulse to growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do expect this year—although we do expect now that it will come slower than, than we had expected and hoped—that there will be relief on the supply side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that, too, should—should lower the supply-side barriers, which are a big part of the story of why inflation is high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, monetary policy will be becoming significantly less accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a case that, for whatever reason, the economy slows more and inflation slows more than expected; we’ll react to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If, instead, we see inflation at a higher level or a more persistent level, then we’ll react to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, we’re, we’re well aware that this is a different economy than—than existed during the last tightening cycle, and our policy is going to reflect those differences.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me—let me—let me start by talking about that last paragraph.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’ll remember during the last cycle that this process of building up and then shrinking the balance sheet is a complicated one, and it involves, inevitably, surprises.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so during, during the years, during the prior cycle, we amended our balance sheet principles a number of times.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, we didn’t intend to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just—events required us to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we got a pretty robust paragraph there that says we’re free to do this at any time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it doesn’t mean we’re going to, but if the situation turns out to be different than we had thought, we’re not going to be—we’re not going to stick with something that isn’t working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s all that’s saying.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s meant to be quite a general statement rather than a, a hint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I mean, I like to think that our, you know, our philosophy of the balance sheet is, is embodied in these principles.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, the idea that, for example, the federal funds rate is the primary means of adjusting the stance of policy, that we’ll use—determine the timing and pace of reducing the size of the balance sheet to foster the dual mandate, that we’ll begin to reduce the size after we begin the process of raising rates, and on and on like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, that—those are all the things that, that try to describe how we will proceed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But maybe at a higher level, to try to get at your question: You know, asset purchases were, were enormously important at the beginning of the recovery in terms of restoring market function, as they were at—right after the—in the critical phase of the Global Financial Crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then after [that], they were a macroeconomic tool to support demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now the economy no longer needs this, this highly accommodative policy that we put in place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s time to stop asset purchases first and then, at the appropriate time, start to shrink the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, the balance sheet is, is substantially larger than it needs to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve identified the end state as—in amounts needed to implement monetary policy efficiently [and] effectively in the ample-reserves regime.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s a substantial amount of, of shrinkage in the balance sheet to be done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want that process to be orderly and predictable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so those are some of the ways that I would think this, this lays out our, you know, the way we—the way we’re thinking about this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the timing, I can’t really help you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it just says after, after we get under way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re—I would say we are, we’re going to have another discussion at, at the next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And my guess is, we’ll have at least one other discussion at the meeting after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ll, we’ll tell you as we make progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll, you know, we’ll start the process of allowing runoff and shrinking the balance sheet at what we find to be the appropriate time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—I wish I could say more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, honestly, we haven’t made those decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we actually haven’t even really had the, the important discussions on a lot of the details that we will have at coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you asked about the risks first.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I—you know, the one risk is that inflation risks are still to the upside in the views of most FOMC participants and, certainly, in my view as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a risk that, that the high inflation we’re seeing will be prolonged, and there’s a risk that it will move even higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t—we don’t think that’s the base case, but you asked what the risks are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s—we have to be in a position with our monetary policy to address all of the plausible outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that calls for us to be in position.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we have an expectation about the way the economy is going to be evolved, but we’ve got to be in a position to, to address different outcomes, including the one where inflation remains higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, that is a risk to the—to the—to the expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve been saying that what we need here is another long expansion, which is the kind of thing we saw over the last [one], which was a record long expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We saw labor force participation rise.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We saw wages persistently higher for people at the lower end, and there, there really was no obvious imbalance in the economy that threatened that expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It could have gone on for years were it not hit by the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’d love to find a way to get back to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s going to require price stability, and that’s going to require the Fed to tighten interest rate policy and do our part in getting inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I mentioned two-sided risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, a couple things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One, Omi—COVID is not over.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And COVID can continue to evolve, and it’s just—we have to accept that it’s not over, and the risks to it can slow down growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that would be—that’s sort of a downside risk from a growth standpoint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would point to—you know, another, another risk is just further, further problems in the supply chains, which could slow down activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see the situation in China as a situation there where that’s—their no-COVID policy may cause more lockdowns, is likely to, and that may play into—may play into more problems in supply chains.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, there’s what’s going on in Eastern Europe and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s plenty of risk out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we, you know, we can’t—we can’t forget that there are risks on both sides.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I know you’ve been all over this issue with, with my colleagues, Craig, on the issue of, of information.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t—we don’t have that information at the Board.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I hand—I asked the inspector general to do an investigation, and that is out of my hands.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I play no role in it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I seek to play no role in it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t—I really—I can’t help you here today on this issue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m sorry I can’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’d say, you know, since, since the December meeting, I would say that the inflation situation is about the same but probably slightly worse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d be inclined to raise my own estimate of 2022 core PCE inflation—let’s just go with that—by a few tenths today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re not writing, writing down an SEP at this meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think it’s—it hasn’t gotten better.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s probably gotten just a—just a bit worse, and that’s been the pattern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s been the pattern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think if you look at the—the FOMC participants are—there’s a range there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that range has been moving to the right for, for a year now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, if you look at other forecasters, essentially all other macro forecasters who do this for a living, you’ve seen the same pattern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think we, you know, we wrote down rate increases in the December meetings, each of us individually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think to the extent the situation deteriorates further, our policy will have to address that, if it deteriorates meaningfully further, either in the time dimension or in the size of the inflation dimension.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I—as I mentioned, though, I think it’s—part of this will be that us, the Fed, moving away from a very highly accommodative policy to a substantially less accommodative policy and then, over time, to a policy that’s not accommodative, in time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know when that will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—those are the things that we’re—that we’re thinking about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s part of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another part of it is that fiscal policy provided an impulse to growth over the last two years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That impulse will be less, in fact, will be—will be negative this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s another thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other one is, we will eventually get relief on the supply side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the ports will be cleared up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there will be semiconductors and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, what we’re learning is, it’s just taking much longer, so I think—longer than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, I think, does raise, raise the risk that high inflation will be more persistent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think we’ll come off of the highs that we saw in the early part of this episode in the—in the spring last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’ll be watching that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, you know, we—our objective is to get inflation back down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also to provide enough support to keep the labor market healthy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market is very, very strong right now, and I think that that strength will continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a—there’s really a shortage of workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see it particularly among production and nonsupervisory workers and people in the lowest quartile.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see very large wage increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mentioned some of the other indicators.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s, that’s what we’re looking at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re also—you know, we realize, I think, as everyone does, that this outlook is quite uncertain and that we’re going to have to adapt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to communicate as clearly as we can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re going to have to be adaptable and, you know, move, move as appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, we have not made these decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We really haven’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and what I can tell you now, though, is that we fully appreciate that this is a different situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look back to where we were in 2015, ’16, ’17, ’18 when we were raising rates, inflation was very close to 2 percent, even below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Unemployment was, was not at our estimates of the natural rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And growth was, you know, in the 2 to 3 percent range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, we have inflation running substantially above 2 percent and, and, you know, more persistently than we would like.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have growth—even in forecasts, even in the somewhat reduced forecast for 2022—we still see growth higher than, substantially higher than what we estimate to be the potential growth rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we see a labor market where, by so many measures, it is historically tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the—you know, in a way, the least tight aspect of it is, is looking at the unemployment rate, which is still below our median estimate of, of [the unemployment rate consistent with] maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at things like quits and job openings, as I mentioned earlier, and wages, you’re seeing—and, and just the ratio of job openings to unemployed—you’re seeing a very, very tight labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, we also know that labor force participation is significantly lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s 1½ percentage points lower than it was in February of 2020.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Maybe a [full] percentage point of that is, is retirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some part of those retirements are, are, you know, related to COVID rather than just regular retirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think there’s, there’s a pool of people out there who could come back into the labor force.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s not happening very quickly, and it may not—it may continue to not happen very quickly as long as the pandemic is on[going].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s, that’s how we think about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made—to your specific question—we really have not addressed those questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll begin to address them as we—as we move into the March meeting and meetings after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it’s more a matter of—I think the problem that we’re—that we’re talking about here is really that people who are on fixed incomes who are living paycheck to paycheck, they’re spending most or all of their—of, of what they’re earning on food, gasoline, rent, heating their—heating, things like that, basic necessities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so inflation right away, right away forces people like that to make very difficult decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really the point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t—I’m not aware of, you know, inflation literally falling more on, on different socioeconomic groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—that’s not the point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The point is, some people are just really in a—prone to suffer more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, for people who are economically well off, inflation isn’t good.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s bad.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: High inflation is, is bad, but they’re going to be able to continue to eat and keep their homes and drive their cars and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s more—so that, that’s really how I think of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we, we have to control inflation for the benefit of all Americans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But part of—part of it is just that it’s particularly hard on people with fixed incomes and low incomes who spent most of their—of their income on necessities, which are—which are experiencing high inflation now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I would not say that I would expect the supply chain issues to be completely worked out by the end of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do not expect them, and I have not expected them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I would say, and I have been saying, is that I expect progress to be made in the second half of this year, mainly—progress because we’re not making much progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at a ton of metrics, you can find some that suggest that delivery times are shorter and inventories in some industries moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, overall, we’re not—we’re not making progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, things like the semiconductor issue are going to—they’re going to be quite a long time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would think they’ll go more than through 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of—so in terms of being too late, I would just say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—our policy needs to be positioned to address the full range of plausible outcomes, as I said, and particularly the possibility that inflation will continue to run higher, more persistently than we’d expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think we are positioned to make the changes in our policy to do that, and, and we’re committed to doing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s really where we are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of your, your question about the, the size of rate increases, we haven’t—we haven’t faced those decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It isn’t possible to sit down here today and tell you with any confidence what the—what the precise path will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in—as we work our way through this, meeting by meeting, we are aware that this is a very different, different expansion, as I’ve said a couple times, with higher inflation, higher growth, a much stronger economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think those differences are likely to be reflected in—in the policy that we implement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no—there’s nothing in our framework about having inflation run below 2 percent so that we would do that, try to achieve that outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the answer to that is, is “no.” What we’re trying to do is get inflation, keep inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s always the, the ultimate goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do that in the service of having inflation—we get to that goal by having inflation average 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if inflation doesn’t average 2 percent over time, then it’s not clear why inflation expectations would be anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that, that’s the way we think about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nothing like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I would say you have a tremendously strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you have growth this year at—forecast to be well above—well above potential.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, people who are forecasting growth think potential growth is around 2 [percent].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Most forecasts [of actual growth] are significantly above that for 2022, and that’s even with, with policy becoming substantially less accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the labor market’s going to be strong for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re—ideally, what we’re trying to achieve is inflation getting back down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re trying to do that in a process that, that, that accomplishes—you know, that will also leave the labor market in a very strong position.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And no one really knows what that will take.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I would say that it isn’t just monetary policy that’s helping inflation get down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll be supply-side improvements, and it’ll be less, less fiscal, you know, less fiscal impulse in all likelihood.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but monetary policy will do our job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is our job to get inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And a situation where, where the two goals are—the two goals can be in tension is a difficult one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I—but I don’t really think they are here, though, because I think a really significant threat to further strengthening in the labor market in the form of higher participation over time is high inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And also, high inflation is taking away the benefits of some of these larger wage increases that we’re seeing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do hope to achieve, and our plan is to achieve, both of those goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: State dependency was particularly around the thought that if we—if we saw a very strong labor market, we would wait to see actual inflation—actual inflation before we tightened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that was a very state-dependent thought because, for a long time, we’d been tightening on the expectation of high inflation, which never appeared.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that was the case for, for a number of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in this particular situation, we will be clearly monitoring incoming data as well as the evolving outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think it’s too soon to write that history, really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what I would say is this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The—if you remember what it felt like at the beginning of the pandemic, literally the global economy shutting down in large part, including our own economy, and people going to their homes for weeks on end in masks, and there are no vaccines, and it could be a really long time to get them, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then, you know, you have—economic activity drops by a shocking amount in one—so there was a real risk of lasting damage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think Congress responded remarkably with the—with the CARES Act, incredibly timely and very powerful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People will—there’ll always be flaws in these things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in real time, it was a remarkable achievement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we responded.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what we were able to do was, you know, stave off a collapse of the financial system at the beginning and make time for what really needed to happen, which was the income replacement and then the recovery that Congress enabled with the CARES Act.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So now, that was a lot of—that was a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what we did was a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, now—so, what we have now is, we have the strongest recovery of any, any country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have—we have a recovery that looks completely unlike other recoveries that we’ve had, because we’ve, we’ve put so much support behind the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re managing the, the relatively high-class problems that come with that, which are high inflation and a labor shortage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and these are serious problems, very serious problems that we, you know, we’re working as hard as we can on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I’m going to leave that to the historians.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And—but look, in 25 years, we’ll look back at this incident, which will be a, you know, 2-, 3-, 4-, 5-year period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll say, you know, we’ll have a—we’ll have a much better basis to make a judgment about the actions that people took.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it was all founded, though, in a—in a very strong reaction to a, you know, to a unique historical event.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I guess I’ll have to leave it at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look for—I hope I’ll be around to see how that looks in 25 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we do monitor the slope of the yield curve, but we don’t control the slope of the yield curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many flat—many factors influence longer-term interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it is something that we watch, and, and you will know that from when we had this issue a few years ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we take it into account, along with many other financial conditions, as we try to assess the implications of all those conditions for the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s one thing I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another is, currently, you’ve got a slope.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you think about 2s to 10s, 2-year Treasury to 10-year Treasury, I think that’s around 75 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s well within the range of a normal—of a normal yield-curve slope.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s something we’re monitoring.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think of it as—I don’t think of it as some kind of an iron law.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we do look at it and try to understand the implications and what it’s telling us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s—but it’s one of many things that we monitor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d—that’s, that’s a good question in, in real time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Obviously, U.S. long-term sovereign debt is an—is an important global asset.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it—and the fact that our rates are so much higher than, than other risk-free sovereign rates around the world may put something of a ceiling on our—on our rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it would really depend on the—on the facts and circumstances at that time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would describe what we’re doing along these lines.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is going to be a year in which we move steadily away from the very highly accommodative monetary policy that we put in place to deal with the—with the economic effects of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s going to involve a number of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s going to involve and does involve finishing asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s going to involve lifting off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s going to involve additional rate increases as appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we, we have—we’re going to write down in March our next assessment of what that might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s going to continue to evolve as the data evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need to be quite adaptable, I think, in our understanding of this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The last thing we’re going to do is, we’re going to have a couple more meetings, I think, to talk about allowing the balance sheet to begin to run off and [to] do so in a predictable manner.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, that’s something that we will also be doing as appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wouldn’t—I don’t think it’s possible to say exactly how this is going to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re, we’re going to need to be, as I’ve mentioned, nimble about this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the economy is quite different this time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve said this several times now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy is quite different.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s stronger.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation is higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market is much, much stronger than it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And growth is above trend, even this year, let alone last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all of those things are going to go into our thinking as we make—as we make monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you asked about financial stability concerns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we, of course, have a financial stability framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what it shows is a number of, of positive aspects of financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you mentioned, really, [the behavior of] asset prices is one of the four.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So asset prices are somewhat elevated, and they reflect a high risk appetite and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t really think asset prices themselves represent a significant threat to financial stability, and that’s because households are in good shape financially than they have been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Businesses are in good shape financially.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Defaults on business loans are low and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The banks are highly capitalized with high liquidity and quite resilient and strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are some concerns in the—in the nonbank financial sector around—still around money market funds, although the SEC is making—has made some very positive proposals there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we also saw some things in the Treasury market during the acute phase of the crisis, which, which we’re looking at ways to address.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, overall, the financial stability vulnerabilities are manageable—are manageable, I would say.
